DataElement.preferredName: Colorectal Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Pathologic Distant Metastasis M Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the distant metastasis for the colon and rectal cancer based on evidence obtained from pathologic examination through completion of definitive surgery.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Information related to pathologic M stage, one criteria of the TMN staging system where  M refers to the presence of metastasis, of a colorectal tumor

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: (ko-lo-REK-tul) Having to do with the colon or the rectum.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pathologic; caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.:One criteria of the TMN staging system.  M refers to the presence of metastasis.

Concepts.definition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 8-28-19 ownership transfer approved by CTEP/B.Campbell; tmt.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Colorectal Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Pathologic M Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A pathologic finding about one or more characteristics of colorectal cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system as they pertain to distant metastases.  There is no pathologic M0 for colorectal cancer. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)_A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Cancer pM1b TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Cancer pM1b TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal cancer with metastases in more than one organ/site or the peritoneum. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Cancer pM1b TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Colorectal cancer with metastases in more than one organ/site or the peritoneum. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Cancer pM1a TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Cancer pM1a TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal cancer with metastasis confined to one organ or site (e.g., liver, lung, ovary, nonregional node). (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Cancer pM1a TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Colorectal cancer with metastasis confined to one organ or site (e.g., liver, lung, ovary, nonregional node). (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal cancer with distant metastasis. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Cancer pM1 TNM Finding v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Colorectal cancer with distant metastasis. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

Concepts.definition: A pathologic finding about one or more characteristics of colorectal cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system as they pertain to distant metastases.  There is no pathologic M0 for colorectal cancer. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)
A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
